text:
In 2025, Analytics Engineers will build Data-Apps


𝐓𝐞𝐜𝐡𝐧𝐨𝐥𝐨𝐠𝐢𝐞𝐬 𝐦𝐚𝐤𝐞 𝐫𝐨𝐥𝐞𝐬 𝐜𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐞.  

Since the rise of cloud data-warehouses and the birth of dbt, data engineers don’t do data transform anymore. SQL speaking people do: the analytics engineers. 

With the rise of generative AI, analytics engineers may build data-apps too. 

This is the reasoning of Marcus with who I got a great conversation last week. 


𝐈𝐭 𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐦𝐲 𝐨𝐰𝐧 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐯𝐢𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬. 

But while Marcus was thinking of analytics engineers making streamlit apps, I think there is space again for SQL. 

Evidence  tagline “Build polished data apps with SQL” goes exactly in that direction. Archie’s team is inspiring. 


𝐈𝐧 2025, 𝐈 𝐡𝐨𝐩𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐦𝐚𝐤𝐞 𝐦𝐲 𝐨𝐰𝐧 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐫𝐢𝐛𝐮𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 with a data-apps framework - for data activation - made for SQL users. 

𝘐𝘧 𝘺𝘰𝘶’𝘳𝘦 𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘳𝘦𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘥 𝘪𝘯 𝘥𝘢𝘵𝘢-𝘢𝘱𝘱𝘴 𝘵𝘰𝘰, 𝘭𝘦𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘮𝘦 𝘢 𝘮𝘦𝘴𝘴𝘢𝘨𝘦, 𝘐’𝘥 𝘭𝘰𝘷𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘩𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘢 𝘤𝘩𝘢𝘵!


What’s your take on this? 

Will SQL users build data-apps? 

What for?

text:
A while ago, I wanted a daily Slack update on which kind of content was most viewed yesterday. It's nothing serious, but it's still fun and something that motivates me in the morning.

Luckily, I had just recorded a hands-on session with Paul Marcombes about BigFunctions. And we discussed exactly this use case and did a quick demo. So I got it up and running in just 5 minutes.

I just published an introduction to BigFunctions (blog and video) - an open-source project that enables analysts to automate data workflows directly from SQL.

Key takeaways:
- Deploy pre-built functions in 5 minutes to GCP
- Send data-driven notifications to Slack
- Enrich data with API responses and AI without engineering support
- Seamless integration with dbt

The best part? It's all SQL-native. No infrastructure management needed.

Link in comments or just click on "Visit my website" under my name.

📢 I'm pleased to share the latest article by Benoit Pimpaud about BigFunctions! 

His article, "Beyond SQL as a Pure Database Syntax," really captures what we're trying to achieve.

I'm happy with this article because it highlights:

•  SQL's limitations for complex analytics.
•  How BigFunctions improves reusability and workflow by bringing functionality and composability to SQL.
•  How it supports a separation of concerns for data teams.

You can read the full article here: https://lnkd.in/eAdEAs9r

article.title: Beyond SQL as a Pure Database Syntax

text:
I recently explored SQL's limitations for analytics in a talk and in my writing, and I stand by these limits 🌶️

But I recently realized that SQL's syntax isn't the real problem. The core issue lies in its underlying semantics – how we actually interact with and understand our data

In tech (and in general), semantics often struggles to keep pace with syntax. In my latest blog post, I explore how modern tooling like Unytics BigFunctions help to bridge this crucial gap between SQL's origins and modern analytics needs

text:
Unifying Analytics Platform: what if you could have one tool to load, transform and activate data?

𝘐 𝘩𝘢𝘥 𝘢 𝘨𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘵 𝘵𝘢𝘭𝘬 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘮𝘰𝘳𝘯𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩 Burak, 𝘊𝘌𝘖 𝘰𝘧 Bruin 𝘢𝘵 DATANOSCO 𝘱𝘰𝘥𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘵 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 Stéphane.


Burak shared his vision to bring an all-in-one data-platform through bruin. 

Here are key elements:

1/ 𝐍𝐎 𝐧𝐨-𝐜𝐨𝐝𝐞! 
Bruin is code and configuration-based first. It's built around standards to fasten development. It makes it versionable in git and easily extensible.

2/ 𝐀𝐥𝐥-𝐢𝐧-𝐨𝐧𝐞 𝐜𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐞𝐬 𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐲𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐠
Bruin can provide templates to get started loading some data from a specific source up to making the data transforms in a opinionated way. If you had to mix different tools, the user experience would be much less fluid. What's more, this considerably reduces the amount of gluing required for data engineers.

3/ 𝐁𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐭 𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐩𝐞𝐧-𝐬𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐜𝐞
Bruin team created ingestr, a wrapper above dlt from dltHub to ingest data from any data-warehouse. Building above top open-source data tools makes bruin benefits from the data-community to get fast and on top. Giving back to open-source is part of the deal.


Thanks a lot Stéphane for the invitation to your podcast! Burak, I will be follow what you build with attention!

resharedPost.text:
All-in-one data-platform with configuration files. Why I love Bruin vision:

𝟏/ 𝐌𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐧-𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚-𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐜𝐤 𝐥𝐢𝐦𝐢𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬
Modern-data-stack brought data tooling for any data service:

- Fivetran for ingestion. 
- dbt Labs for transform.
- Hightouch for activation. 
- Prefect for orchestration
- SYNQ for reliability
- CastorDoc for catalog

This has been seen as a revolution. 
Whatever your need, there's a tool for it.

BUT is also led to a common criticism. 

👉 You still need to choose, understand, buy and manage all of these tools from different vendors. 🤦‍♂️


𝟐/ 𝐇𝐞𝐥𝐥𝐨 𝐚𝐥𝐥-𝐢𝐧-𝐨𝐧𝐞 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚-𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐬
That's when all-in-one data-platforms came in.
Y42 brings a one-stop-shop for companies to handle their data-platforms. 

Problem solved!

BUT, y42 only runs inside y42.

👉 Hello vendor lock-in. 🤦‍♂️


𝟑/ 𝐁𝐫𝐮𝐢𝐧: 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐧𝐞𝐰 𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐲𝐞𝐫 𝐢𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐠𝐚𝐦𝐞
That's when Bruin entered the game. 

They provide a all-in-one data-platform with ingestion, SQL transform, python jobs (for custom load, transform or activation), and orchestration.

It works locally, it's mostly open-source, and you can run it everywhere. 

Did I mention it also comes with a VS code extension to streamline development?

I am impressed about what they built in a year.  


Do you share my enthusiasm? Why not?

comments.text:
One thing that existing semi-closed source all in one platforms (also like Keboola) are doing but it is not mentioned here:

They bring opinionated ways of doing things and often break the status quo in this space - new tools are created on a daily basis but they do cement the dependency of the whole company on the data team.

The current tooling is often heavy code-only. Whereas this is a good thing for version control, quality assurance etc, it blocks the rest of the company to do a slight work in it, and resorts them to be more or less passive users of the BI tools.

Whenever I have seen a successful broader use of new data tools - it was when they introduced more user-friendly ways to do things, like widgets and interactive elements in Hex or Deepnote for instance. Those are good examples of attempts to make things user friendly.

I do salute to any new kid in the block in the data tooling space, especially when its pushing the data platform vision, though I am missing a revolutionary approach here to make using data simpler, rather then never ending coding in python and YAML hell.

I think we still have a long road to go to have simplified ways of doing things and reach a true democratization of the data within companies. 🤞

text:
All-in-one data-platform with configuration files. Why I love Bruin vision:

𝟏/ 𝐌𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐧-𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚-𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐜𝐤 𝐥𝐢𝐦𝐢𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬
Modern-data-stack brought data tooling for any data service:

- Fivetran for ingestion. 
- dbt Labs for transform.
- Hightouch for activation. 
- Prefect for orchestration
- SYNQ for reliability
- CastorDoc for catalog

This has been seen as a revolution. 
Whatever your need, there's a tool for it.

BUT is also led to a common criticism. 

👉 You still need to choose, understand, buy and manage all of these tools from different vendors. 🤦‍♂️


𝟐/ 𝐇𝐞𝐥𝐥𝐨 𝐚𝐥𝐥-𝐢𝐧-𝐨𝐧𝐞 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚-𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐬
That's when all-in-one data-platforms came in.
Y42 brings a one-stop-shop for companies to handle their data-platforms. 

Problem solved!

BUT, y42 only runs inside y42.

👉 Hello vendor lock-in. 🤦‍♂️


𝟑/ 𝐁𝐫𝐮𝐢𝐧: 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐧𝐞𝐰 𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐲𝐞𝐫 𝐢𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐠𝐚𝐦𝐞
That's when Bruin entered the game. 

They provide a all-in-one data-platform with ingestion, SQL transform, python jobs (for custom load, transform or activation), and orchestration.

It works locally, it's mostly open-source, and you can run it everywhere. 

Did I mention it also comes with a VS code extension to streamline development?

I am impressed about what they built in a year.  


Do you share my enthusiasm? Why not?

author.occupation: Finance, Artificial Intelligence (AI) & Sustainability

comments.text:
One thing that existing semi-closed source all in one platforms (also like Keboola) are doing but it is not mentioned here:

They bring opinionated ways of doing things and often break the status quo in this space - new tools are created on a daily basis but they do cement the dependency of the whole company on the data team.

The current tooling is often heavy code-only. Whereas this is a good thing for version control, quality assurance etc, it blocks the rest of the company to do a slight work in it, and resorts them to be more or less passive users of the BI tools.

Whenever I have seen a successful broader use of new data tools - it was when they introduced more user-friendly ways to do things, like widgets and interactive elements in Hex or Deepnote for instance. Those are good examples of attempts to make things user friendly.

I do salute to any new kid in the block in the data tooling space, especially when its pushing the data platform vision, though I am missing a revolutionary approach here to make using data simpler, rather then never ending coding in python and YAML hell.

I think we still have a long road to go to have simplified ways of doing things and reach a true democratization of the data within companies. 🤞

text:
How to stay fast in a bigger company? Here's what I learnt during the last decade:

I started working 13 years ago in medical imaging. 
We were 5 people in the company. 
We built ultrasound scanners from end to end. 
I was impressed by our speed compared to our competitors.

It was because we were small. 
Us, engineers, were in direct contact with doctors. 
We were able to discover their problems in the morning and ship solutions in the afternoon.

At that time I thought that competitors with hundreds of employees were unlucky. 
They would never be as fast as us. 
Their flow from idea to delivery contained too numerous asphixying steps.

This was before I came to Nickel. 


👉 At Nickel, I realized that you can be 900 employees and still be fast.

One way is to get autonomous teams 
while respecting big companies requirements. 

One key for this is to create a FRAMEWORK which:

✅ is a space of trust in which teams can make their own decisions. 
✅ defines guidelines and standards (security, compliance, brand, etc.). 
✅ defines boundaries that limit teams inter-dependencies.
✅ comes with platform tools & platform teams to go faster while harmonizing the work. 


For example:

❌ BAD ➜ teams depend on CENTRAL BOTTLENECK committees for validation of everything. Even minor initiatives.

✅ GOOD ➜ security team gives you the autonomy to build stuff while helping you to follow cybersecurity standards. 

👉 AVOID bottlenecks & EMPOWER people within a FRAMEWORK.


I may give details of how we did for Nickel data people in a next post. 
Stay tuned.


I wish you a Happy New Year!

text:
Just tried something really amazing with BigFunctions by Paul Marcombes.

BigFunctions lets you use Python functions directly in BigQuery, and thanks to its prebuilt functions, you can even run LLMs through SQL. It’s a great way to extend BigQuery’s capabilities without needing external tools.

In my case, I wanted to quickly get foundational details (country, city, and year of establishment) for some well-known football teams. Using the ask_ai function, I was able to send a simple prompt, get structured responses, and parse them—all within BigQuery.

This is just one example, but there’s a lot more you can do with it. It’s a practical tool that simplifies working with AI and Python in a SQL environment.
Big thanks to Paul for building and sharing this!

text:
Static BI is going to be huge!  Here's why I am VERY excited 🤯:


Static BI is about creating interactive dashboards on top of Parquet files. 

It's trending since we can run duckdb in the browser. 

If you follow this area, you already know Observable and Evidence tools. 


But I am pretty sure you don't know mozaic yet. 


➜ Mozaic Dashboards are interactive, fast, based on parquet files and they can deal with a lot of data.

➜ What make them great in my opinion is that you can generate them on the fly using a simple yaml configuration AND with vanilla javascript. 

NO MORE front-end build or deployment needed! 


This opens a wide new area for static BI. 

In the example of the screenshot, I am downloading a YAML configuration file from another website and generating the dashboard on the fly with it! 

It means that we can share YAML configurations templates for common dashboards on common analyses 😲. 

The example is in the comment. Don't hesitate to play with it. It's fun.


In your opinion, is there a place for static BI?
What would you use it for?

text:
GA4 data is known to be hard to explore in BigQuery. But this will change:


Ali Izadi built dozens of handy SQL queries to cover areas like 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘁, 𝘀𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘂𝘀𝗲𝗿 𝘀𝗰𝗼𝗽𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗹𝘆𝘀𝗶𝘀, 𝙚𝙘𝙤𝙢𝙢𝙚𝙧𝙘𝙚 𝙢𝙚𝙩𝙧𝙞𝙘𝙨, 𝙩𝙧𝙖𝙛𝙛𝙞𝙘 𝙖𝙩𝙩𝙧𝙞𝙗𝙪𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙣 𝙎𝙀𝙊 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝘼𝙙𝙨.

It's free, it's open source. It's available in 'Bigquery-GA4-Queries' GitHub repo. 


We built together with Ali an integration of 'Bigquery-GA4-Queries' on bigfunctions.

By calling a bigfunction, you will automatically create all the queries of the GitHub repo as table functions in your GCP project.


We hope it will make it even easier to get started with these awesome queries. 

Links are in comments. Please add a star to Ali's repo if you want to support his work.

text:
Mkdocs or docusaurus to build your data documentation website?


Both tools are used by millions of developers everyday to deploy their documentation website. 

Which one to choose?


➜  It depends if your a pythonist or a front end engineer. 


With docusaurus you can mix mardown with react components. It brings huge possibilities in an elegant mannner. 

But if you’re not a front end engineer but a pythonist you will find docusaurus over complicated and would rather stick with mkdocs (using Mkdocs material or readthedoc themes). 



☝ I feel the same for bi as code tools. 

Observable and evidence.dev look absolutely awesome to me. 

But as a pythonist I think we can do simpler. 

I am even considering making bi as code  with a simple mkdocs plugin. 

Would you be interested? 

Am I wrong with the above thoughts?

comments.text:
I'm maybe biaised because I'm kinda full stack (and did my fair share of React & Typescript, maybe more than Python).

I picked Docusaurus and Observable.dev for my own projects as I really like the power of standardizing most of the content around Markdown and yet be able to go as far as I need with custom components.

The fact that javascript is running in the browser allows much more possibilities than Python based apps that always require a server.

text:
Introducing the SQL Declarative-Data-Stack! 


Modern Data Stack have tools to do everything with data. 

Everything EXCEPT custom stuff.

➜ you end up with a ton of python scripts floating around. 


Kestra aims to solve this. 

They propose a central tool to orchestrate your jobs in a declarative way. 


We propose ANOTHER way.

We propose you simply use dbt instead (or sqlmesh or dataform).

It means all your jobs must be callable from SQL. 

Which is easy nowadays. 

As data-warehouses natively do python callable from SQL.


What if you could easily build :

-  a catalog 
-  of advanced functions
-  callable by anyone from SQL
-  & defined in a declarative manner

?


Say hi to the SQL Declarative-Data-Stack!


What's your opinion on this? 

Would you be ready to do everything from SQL? 

If not, Why?

comments.text:
Totalement en phase avec l'idée de généraliser les transformations en SQL 👍 . C'est Personnellement, ce que je pousse depuis des années d'ailleurs.
Certes, le langage n'est pas parfait mais son manque de formalisme le rend aussi plus accessible, universel et partageable par tout type de profil, IT, Data, Métiers.

A l'époque, le principal défaut des ETL historiques (DataStage, Talend, PowerCenter et d'autres...) était précisément qu'il fallait jongler entre le SQL dans les bases de données et les boites + flèches dès que l'on en sortait. Cela conduisait à des implémentations techniques de règles métiers plus ou moins farfelues en fonction des besoins de performance.

SparkSQL a été l'une des premières implémentation à changer cela et d'autres, comme dbt, SQLMesh, DuckDB, ont suivi depuis. Ça va dans le sens de l'histoire et de la démocratisation de l'accès aux données 😊 .

text:
I aim to build and define the data stack with a "single function", including the entire data engineering lifecycle, starting up a full #declarativedatastack. 

```
run_stack(
  serve(
    template='github://covid/covid_dashboard.md',
    data=transform(
      {
        'groupby': 'country',
        'aggregate': {
          'cases': 'sum',
          'deaths': 'sum'
        }
      },
      ingest(
        source='duckdb',
        query='SELECT * FROM "s3://coviddata/covid_*.parquet"'
      )
    )
  )
)
```

I'm thinking something like this (images attached). The "engine" is basically only transpiling from config to the actual data stack with multiple adapters— e.g., dbt, SDF, SQLMesh for `transform()`.

I can't help but think about DWH Automation (DWA). 

> Config = template
> Engine = DWA
> DDS = generated SQLs

If you were to implement a declarative data stack engine (DDSE), would you focus on the *one-time* generation of a data stack (second image attached) or the continuous update?

What I mean is, would you fix or update configs/templates as DWA did or the artifacts (SQL, YAMLs) without touching the generated code? 

Any thoughts? 🤔 Gregor Zeiler, Jan Kaul, Matthew Kosovec and others in my network?

comments.text:
Hey Simon Späti!

This looks interesting for simple use cases and point-to-point solutions, but I would encourage you to take the thoughts further and think about how this would scale out to thousands of integrations and/or transformations.

You are offloading the transform to sub-processors (like dbt, SDF, SQLMesh) but how are you planning to manage cross-dependencies between functions? The frameworks you mentioned are all imperative/procedural at their core. As you dig in - I think you will see this quickly becomes building an orchestration platform because you have one sub-element that is non-declarative in your framework's stack (see Dagster).

How will your transpiler work? Are you going to build a SQL generator to map from your declarative object model within transform({}) to well-formed SQL, broken down intelligently into multiple models to balance code cleanliness and performance? Will it be human-readable and easy to debug?

Finally - and probably most importantly - how is your declarative stack definition going to interface with LLM code generation? Will this structure make translating natural language into good architecture easier? This new "user" of code frameworks will arguable become the most important.

comments.text:
This is a great discussion, Simon!
To answer your question: I would focus on continuous updating.

The reason for me is simple and just like the old DWA days.
If the entire lifecycle is not supported and automated, the effect is reduced to a one-time effect. I.e. little benefit and savings.

Another very important reason for me is that the declarative datastack is the basis for natural language data engineering to work.
Natural language data engineering (AI powered, AI copiloted, AI...) is what companies absolutely need. Data engineering for everyone in the company.

Simon, I would love to talk about this.

text:
These days I write a lot about getting data from various different digital platforms into #BigQuery*. The GA4 native export is getting a lot of traction, but there are other data sources as well e.g. through the BigQuery Data Transfer and other native export mechanisms.

But there is even more. BigFunctions by Unytics offers even more extremely convenient ways to bring data into BigQuery. For example, it is now possible to ingest #GoogleTrends data through the API with a simple function call:

select bigfunctions.eu.get_google_trends('bigquery', null, 'today 5-y', null, null)
🤩 🚀 

Sure, the output will need to be unpacked with JSON / array functions, but still, a good few hours or days can be saved especially if you don’t have data engineering resources at your disposal.

Google Trends data can be useful for many reasons, but one can be to check the overall “global” trends of keywords when a website’s organic traffic shows a significant decline for these keywords. Checking what’s going on “outside” the #SearchConsole data can help troubleshoot whether we’re dealing with an SEO issue or a decline in interest (i.e. an economical situation).

This is not an affiliate post. It’s a happy user & fan post. BigFunctions is just soo handy, and free, with many functions ready to use in BigQuery without any setup or “installation”. (Thanks Paul Marcombes)

Enjoy and leverage Google Trends data!

–
Follow me for posts on #digitalmarketing #analytics and #BigQuery, and hit the bell on my profile to receive updates.

—
(* “These days I write a lot about getting data from various different digital platforms into BigQuery”. That is, if I find the time to write - I’m snowed under these days so I’m not posting as much as I would like.)

text:
I was impressed by Sherloq this week.

Sherloq is a tool to organize and share your SQL queries.

What caught my eye is the UX:

text:
Self-served data-analysts are much more impactful. Here’s why: 


We often talk about self-service analytics. 

It’s a way to democratize data access in a company. It focuses on all people. 

But we forget to think about self-service for data-analysts. 

Company people used to be dependent on data-analysts to access data. Self-service analytics changed that. 

Data-analysts are still dependent on data-engineers to do their job. Self-service for data-analysts change that.  

What if data engineers became data-platform engineers, building a catalog of tools that the data-analysts could pick to achieve their job?

Self-served data-analysts would not be dependent anymore. 

It would open much more scalability to answer data needs. 

It would foster creativity. 

It would boost data activation. 


What’s your opinion on this?


———

BigFunctions was built to reach self-served data analysts. It provides them a catalog of services to do everything they need from SQL.

text:
Text to SQL may not be the answer for self service analytics. 


Text to SQL is great as a coding assistant for Data Analysts. 

But it won’t help for business people to get trusted data answers. 


The problem is that SQL can be quite complex. The LLM has too much freedom. It can generate incorrect stuff too easily. 

It’s OK for a coding assistant. The data analyst will fix it and iterate. It is not acceptable for a CEO. 

You have to constrain stuff. 


We can make the LLM generate requests on a semantic layer instead of SQL. 


Another way would be to have a set of templated queries with parameters. 

The LLM would choose among the templates and guess the correct parameter values. 

For example: 

- A template sql query could be the select of an aggregate of a metric over time with a breakdown on a dimension. 

- Parameters would be the table name, the aggregate function, the metric and the dimension.


Thanks David Jayatillake  & Naim Kosayyer for opening my eyes on this at Forward Data Conference.

comments.text: Totally agree. SQL is one of those languages that intrinsically carry a ton of hidden context. As stated, the complexity of the data makes it very difficult to condense it down into a text to sql environment (and I'm making a presumption that text to sql is an AI assisted utility to generate sql). For example, some tables may carry a column called Active, but that's one aspect of their status, because you also or alternatively need to look at a date field and it's relationship to another date or perhaps "today's" date.

comments.text:
fully agree that Text-to-SQL has significant limitations, especially for non-technical users. The main issue is mapping user intent into reliable, reproducible queries that align with the underlying data and governance frameworks. The LLM’s “freedom to guess” is a major risk + the semantic gap between natural language and database schemas is too wide

I've also been thinking a lot about runtime query validation pipelines.

- The LLM generates a semantic layer request or maps parameters to a query template.
- A query validation layer performs structural checks (e.g., schema alignment, join validity) and logical checks (e.g., are requested metrics or dimensions consistent with business rules?).
- If anomalies are detected, the system provides immediate feedback or fallback options

text:
BigFunctions is a framework like dbt to supercharge your data-warehouse:

1/  
- functions are deployed in yaml
- dbt models are declared in yaml/sql. 

2/ 
- functions are tested and deployed with a command line. 
- dbt models are tested and deployed with a command line. 

3/ 
- in both frameworks the command line generates a documentation website. 


> With dbt and bigfunctions you can then build a all-in-one data-platform as a declarative data stack.

author.occupation: data & analytics

comments.text:
SQLMesh brings a nice concept to bridge the gap between dev and prod. However, I still don’t understand how you make sure ingested data is the same between dev and prod.

For tranformation layer, as you split dev and prod using virtual layer, that already makes sense. However, ingested data will be different especially when you ingest data from a new source that needs to be tested first on dev before deployed to prod. And when you deploy to prod, switching views on the Virtual layer is not enough. You need to also deploy the pipelines to ingest the same data on Prod.

Thus, I think SQLMesh only covers the Virtual Layer concept for the transformation layer (Silver/Gold), but not the raw/ingestion layer (Bronze).

Dans cet épisode, nous avons le plaisir de recevoir Paul Marcombes, Head of Data chez Nickel, afin d'échanger sur la plateforme de données en temps réel qu'ils ont mise en place et son impact dans le secteur bancaire.

🔥 Au programme :

> L’adoption du modèle de Data Mesh chez Nickel et son impact sur l’organisation de l’équipe data. 
> Un tour d’horizon des technologies et outils utilisés, notamment l’architecture de la plateforme de données en temps réel. 
> L’utilisation de cette plateforme pour répondre aux enjeux marketing et de conformité dans un contexte bancaire.

Pour l'écouter ça se passe ici 👇

article.title: Comment Nickel transforme son entreprise grâce à l'IA | De l'analyse client à l'innovation produit

text:
[Replay du vendredi] Comment Nickel transforme son entreprise grâce à l'IA

🚀 Paul Marcombes, Head of Data de Nickel, présente comment l'entreprise utilise l'IA pour améliorer l’expérience client et les processus internes.

Il présente comment Nickel associe moteurs de recherche et génération de contenu pour créer des solutions IA adaptées. 

Son message essentiel: Bien séparer la partie moteur de recherche de la partie génération de contenu. Les utilisateurs veulent voir la vraie data !

Avec ce retour d'expérience, Paul met en avant une solution simple permettant aux utilisateurs de questionner les retours des clients sur des plateformes comme l’App Store ou Trustpilot via du RAG et de la recherche hybride, adaptées à la gestion rapide et efficace des informations pour les équipes.

Nickel compte aujourd'hui 4 millions de comptes ouverts en 10 ans, une présence dans 5 pays et 11 000 points partenaires en Europe. L'entreprise a 200 utilisateurs SQL qui exploitent les insights des données.

Voici le lien : https://lnkd.in/etG5e9P3

text:
Do you have a lot of text data? ➜ Categorize it! ✨

The easiest way to get a holistic view of your text data is to categorize it. 

You'll instantly get:

➜ the main topics, 
➜ the number of texts associated to each,
➜ the evolution of these metrics over time


Here's an example of how I've categorized our user reviews at Nickel.
I'm impressed by the results.


It can also be applied to customer support tickets.

It can also be applied to the Information schema of your database to get a business classification of your tables. 

What other use cases do you see?

comments.text:
This is actually pretty difficult to do in practice. I have worked on this problem and just using AI in a single pass doesn't cut it. Let me explain the problem. 

Let's say we have 1 million short descriptions of something and we want to extract categories from each description. Sure, we can just feed the data to an AI model but each call to the API is independent of each other, a lot of extracted categories will overlap with each other semantically but with different keywords. What we really want is to represent each semantically different concept with a different keyword, neither is this possible with independent AI calls for each sentence not feeding the entire dataset into AI. 

I would really love to know if you are doing something else here.

text:
I just tried the brand new 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐲𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐬 from Looker Studio. Here's 👇 what I learnt 

All BI teams are working hard to enable users to get insights from natural language questions.

Looker Studio is no exception. Here's what I learnt trying their new Conversational Analytics UI:


𝐆𝐞𝐭𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐛𝐞𝐭𝐭𝐞𝐫!
➡️  It works great to explore a table
➡️  𝘏𝘰𝘸 𝘸𝘢𝘴 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘤𝘢𝘭𝘤𝘶𝘭𝘢𝘵𝘦𝘥? exposes very clearly how AI provided the answer and quikly gives you trust in the answer. 
➡️  𝘐𝘯𝘴𝘪𝘨𝘩𝘵𝘴 exposes result interpretation in natural language which is great to copy paste in a presentation
➡️  𝘘𝘶𝘦𝘴𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘴 𝘚𝘶𝘨𝘨𝘦𝘴𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘴 are interested to get started
➡️  𝘚𝘶𝘨𝘨𝘦𝘴𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘴 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘳𝘦𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘮𝘶𝘭𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 work very well


𝐓𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞'𝐬 𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐚 𝐥𝐨𝐭 𝐭𝐨 𝐝𝐨
➡️  Charts are limited. I found no way for the Agent to result a chart showing the evolution of a metric with a break down on a dimension. Quite restricting for an analysis...
➡️  Agent can give you a precise information contained in the table. But forget about asking advanced stuff such as making a feature impact analysis or compare distribution of a metric between two periods. 
➡️  Actually it can only answer one unique result at a time. You cannot generate multiple charts at once with analysis by different dimensions. 


𝐒𝐡𝐨𝐮𝐥𝐝 𝐈 𝐮𝐬𝐞 𝐋𝐨𝐨𝐤𝐞𝐫 𝐒𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐢𝐨 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐲𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐬?
➡️  I think it is already an interesting tool to expose some prepared data to end users who are not proficient in SQL nor dashboarding
➡️  But if you're a data analyst you would prefer to use BigQuery Canvas which enables to tune your queries and better manage the flow between questions & answers. 


𝐒𝐡𝐨𝐮𝐥𝐝 𝐈 𝐥𝐨𝐨𝐤 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐨𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫 𝐭𝐨𝐨𝐥𝐬?
The improvement of these tools to enable advanced analysis use cases is just a matter of time. You should definitely keep an eye on what's coming to be ready when it comes. 

I won't we surprised if open-source wins. 

If you're more from engineering here are two tools you want to have a look at:
- #Lida from Microsoft to automate charts from data. 
- #opendataqna from Google to query your database in natural language. 


𝐖𝐡𝐚𝐭'𝐬 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐧 𝐢𝐧 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐚𝐧𝐲?


#conversationalanalytics #bigquery #lookerstudio #genai

Photo by Guilherme Stecanella on Unsplash

text:
Data Analysis: Is Structured Data Enough?

You can be the greatest data-analyst, you will never be able to uncover an insight for which you don't have the data. 

Structured data is great: it shows you facts and correlations between phenomena that characterize your product's current situation. 

But you're missing out a ton. 

You can't see what your users are thinking, what they want, what frustrates them. 


I think data analysts should incorporate the “voice of the customer” into their data and take their data analysis to a new level. 


I'll be explaining how to do this in practice at a conference at the Salon Data IA in Nantes, France. 


Come and join us!
➡️ https://lnkd.in/eevGPnGc

text:
Surface the search behind the RAG 🔎 !

Retrieval Augmented Generation is one of the best way to get started with GenAI in a company. 

Mathilde Gorieu made us realize at Nickel that while it's very powerful to help people find information from a knowledge base, it does not always offer the best user experience with regard to the use case. 

So instead of embedding a hidden search engine into your RAG system, it's better to decouple search and RAG and offer a User Experience with both functionalities. 



Thanks Isabella Busch & C2C for the invitation to share this at Google Paris Office with guillaume blaquiere Antoine Castex Mehdi Labassi Rhys Phillips Guillaume Gelin Josh S. text:
🦸 BigQuery Champions, Level Up Your Data Work with BigFunctions!
Data engineers, are you tired of manually building and managing BigQuery functions? 
BigFunctions is revolutionizing your workflow!

💡Created by data guru Paul Marcombes, the open-source project BigFunctions offers 100+ functions ready to implement for your BigQuery projects. 

The most common BigFunctions use cases are:

• Expand functionality. Despite the array of functions available in BigQuery, there might be occasions where a specific function is needed but not included.
• Streamline your queries: UDFs act like reusable code snippets in BigQuery. Instead of rewriting the same complicated calculations over and over, define them once as a UDF and then simply reference them wherever needed.
• Standardization. UDFs act like a playbook for your queries. By creating a UDF for a particular calculation, you ensure everyone is using the same definition, promoting consistency across large teams or complex organizations.

Check out BigFunctions and what it help you do in our article (link in the comments)

text:
Refresh a Tableau Workbook with a SQL command

dbt provides post-hooks.

Post-hooks are SQL queries that run after model creation.

Refresh_tableau is a function available to anyone in BigQuery to trigger the refresh of a Tableau source with SQL.

One can then refresh a Tableau Workbook at the minute its dbt model is re-computed, thanks to a dbt post-hook. 

Many Thanks Antoine Giraud for having created this function in BigFunctions


#bigquery #bigfunctions

text:
The stuff no one will tell you about running a data team:
 
1. You'll might need to say NO to more stuff
2. You can say NO to more stuff
3. You should say NO to more stuff 
4. You have to say NO to more stuff 
5. You will fail if you don't say NO to more stuff 

Everyone thinks they need to please everyone when they take on a role in data.

In reality, you need to get really great at saying NO to low-value requests.

Otherwise, your team will be a low-value team.

__

As a data leader this is your most important job.

Find the high-value stuff, and say NO to everything else.

comments.text:
Absolutely agree. Need to understand your resources, and appreciate the value added to the company. Avoid doing the projects that might save someone 10 minutes a week to pull their report, when automating it will take 2 weeks of developer time.

Also, using gold standard reporting data sets, and making almost all requests for new reports stand on them, with variations added last mile, avoids having to to build custom transforms for every report. Spending time in carefully selecting and designing your downstream tables/transforms will save you a lot of time.

text:
Stop struggling with nested JSON in BigQuery! 🤼‍♂️ Flatten your data 🚀

𝐓𝐢𝐫𝐞𝐝 𝐨𝐟 𝐞𝐧𝐝𝐥𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐥𝐲 𝐧𝐚𝐯𝐢𝐠𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐟𝐢𝐞𝐥𝐝𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐉𝐒𝐎𝐍 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚? 😩
You're not alone. It's like searching for a needle in a haystack...made of objects and arrays! 🤯


𝐁𝐮𝐭 𝐰𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐢𝐟 𝐈 𝐭𝐨𝐥𝐝 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞'𝐬 𝐚 𝐛𝐞𝐭𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝐰𝐚𝐲? 🎉
Introducing the new BigQuery function 𝘴𝘲𝘭_𝘵𝘰_𝘧𝘭𝘢𝘵𝘵𝘦𝘯_𝘫𝘴𝘰𝘯_𝘤𝘰𝘭𝘶𝘮𝘯 which parses your json column, guesses the json schema and generates a SQL query to execute to flatten the json column. 


✨ Say goodbye to nested chaos: Transform complex JSON structures into easy-to-manage flat tables. 
✨ Query with confidence: Easily access any field without writing convoluted nested queries. 
✨ Boost your productivity: Spend less time wrangling data and more time extracting insights

Ready to ditch the JSON struggle?

text:
Loading data into BigQuery should be as simple as a SQL query 👅 !

Airbyte built awesome open-source connectors to move data into your warehouse. 


𝘞𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘪𝘧 𝘸𝘦 𝘤𝘰𝘶𝘭𝘥 𝘳𝘶𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘮 𝘷𝘪𝘢 𝘢 𝘴𝘪𝘮𝘱𝘭𝘦 𝘚𝘘𝘓 𝘲𝘶𝘦𝘳𝘺? 


That's what this function does. You can get data from any public GitHub Repo into your BigQuery project (no install required). It uses Airbyte Github connector under the hood. 

This could work for any Airbyte python connectors. 

Imagine that all you needed was an SQL query to obtain data from any source 😲

𝘞𝘩𝘪𝘤𝘩 𝘴𝘰𝘶𝘳𝘤𝘦 𝘴𝘩𝘰𝘶𝘭𝘥 𝘸𝘦 𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘰𝘳𝘪𝘵𝘪𝘻𝘦?


Function documentation in comments.


#bigquery #airbyte #bigfunctions #googlecloud #dataengineering

text:
Build your own catalog of BigQuery functions 🌌


I like this article from Jake Holmquist ☁️ as it describes the two sides of bigfunctions:

➡️ 𝐄𝐟𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐚𝐜𝐜𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐭𝐨 𝐚𝐝𝐯𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞𝐝 𝐁𝐢𝐠𝐐𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐟𝐮𝐧𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬: No installation. Just new SQL power at your fingertips. 🤯

➡️ 𝐁𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐨𝐰𝐧 𝐠𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐧𝐞𝐝 𝐟𝐮𝐧𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐚𝐥𝐨𝐠: Empower your team with a centralized, secure, and reusable function library. 🏗️


While the first side is well-known, I am not sure about the second one. 

Yet the benefits of building a catalog of functions with BigFunctions are many:

✅  Give new power to Data Analysts such as calling your company APIs
✅  Promote consistency with a standard to define functions
✅  Enable discoverability with a searchable web catalog
✅  Use software engineering best practices


🙏 Jake Holmquist ☁️

https://lnkd.in/eJNs-6x5

#bigquery #bigfunctions #googlecloud #dataengineering

resharedPost.text:
BigFunctions now supports UDAF (User-Defined Aggregate Functions) for BigQuery! 🐣 

BigFunctions is a public and open-source catalog of over 100 functions for BigQuery. And the best part? It is incredibly easy to use — everything is already accessible within BigQuery from its public dataset! 💎 

As part of this release, I have created a simple weighted_average function to serve as an example. (I admit, I was not inspired 😅)

And because the world of open source works with the sum of individual contributions, you can also contribute in two ways:
 ∙  1️⃣  If you have inspiration, ideas, or desires, let me know in the comments.
 ∙  2️⃣  If you want to contribute yourself, reach out to me. I will show easy it is thanks to the incredible work of Paul Marcombes! (Bonus: it is the perfect repo for your first steps into the world of open-source. Looks great on a CV 😎 )

As always, the documentation and repository links are in the comments!

text:
I am quite excited with PyAirbyte 😲  (Airbyte connectors available from python)

Airbyte (𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘭𝘦𝘢𝘥𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘰𝘱𝘦𝘯-𝘴𝘰𝘶𝘳𝘤𝘦 𝘴𝘰𝘭𝘶𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 𝘵𝘰 𝘮𝘰𝘷𝘦 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘥𝘢𝘵𝘢 𝘵𝘰 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘥𝘢𝘵𝘢-𝘸𝘢𝘳𝘦𝘩𝘰𝘶𝘴𝘦) finally released their connectors as python packages. They even released a package (PyAirbyte) to easily use them from python.

This is great news as:

✅  PyAirbyte is standalone: you don't need to install and run an airbyte server anymore! 
✅  Python practitioners only need to write < 10 line of code to move data from any source to the data-warehouse
✅  Deployment can be done easily on serverless compute such as Github Actions, Gitlab CI, Cloud Run Jobs, Lambda functions, etc.


I created AirbyteServerless last year to solve these exact problems and I am very happy that Airbyte could take some inspiration of it to offer an even better solution. Great work Aaron ("AJ") Steers ! 👏 🎉  


Announcement Blog Post: https://lnkd.in/eAc8TfS6

AirbyteServerless GitHub: https://lnkd.in/eYKPJtey


#dataengineering #airbyte

Photo from Alexander Krivitskiy from unsplash

text:
What is a Staff Analytics-Engineer and why we need them? 


𝐄𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐝 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚-𝐩𝐞𝐨𝐩𝐥𝐞 𝐢𝐧 𝐭𝐞𝐚𝐦𝐬 𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐞

One way to scale data analysis is to 𝘦𝘮𝘣𝘦𝘥 𝘥𝘢𝘵𝘢 𝘱𝘦𝘰𝘱𝘭𝘦 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘦𝘢𝘮𝘴, tribes, domains. You give them the autonomy on the whole data chain including transforms.

Because teams are autonomous to collect data, transform it and expose it to others, 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘢𝘷𝘰𝘪𝘥 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘣𝘰𝘵𝘵𝘭𝘦𝘯𝘦𝘤𝘬 of depending on a central data-team for these tasks. It then gets easier to scale. 


𝐁𝐮𝐭 𝐝𝐨𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐬𝐨, 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐜𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐚 𝐫𝐢𝐬𝐤. 

Data people in teams could come to work differently, with different tools. This can lead to silos with less shareable knowledge. It may become hard to maintain and not optimal. 


𝐎𝐧𝐞 𝐰𝐚𝐲 𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐨𝐥𝐯𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐢𝐬 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐠𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐬

Guilds are communities of data people with shared interests such as analytics engineering to share knowledge, tools code and practices. 

While guilds are great you may want to have people working full time to improve practices. 


𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐟𝐟 𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐲𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐬 𝐄𝐧𝐠𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐫 𝐑𝐨𝐥𝐞

We had a great talk last week from Martin Lang et Dimitri Antakly from Decathlon Digital who introduced their role: Staff Analytics Engineer.


The Staff Analytics-Engineer is in the central data team and:

✅  Takes a step back to improve the analytics engineering practices
✅  Animates the community of data-people working on transforms
✅  Helps data-people and Provides guidelines
✅  Tests new tools

Martin and Dimitri gave a great example of their added value: 

They identified a problem of re-work between tribes and they (with the community) decided to create a shared dbt zone with shared transforms between the sources and the tribes transforms.


🙏 Martin and Dimitri for this very inspiring talk.
🙏 Stéphane Heckel from DATANOSCO for organizing this great Modern-Data Stack conference
🙏 Criteo for hosting the conference


#datanalytics #analyticsengineering #dataengineering

text:
What if data-analysts could take actions themselves 🏀? 


We had a great presentation from Tangi Gouez and Manuel Cellier from Dashlane last week at Nickel. They told us their tips to take the most of data-analysts in an organization:

💬 "𝘛𝘩𝘦𝘺 𝘮𝘶𝘴𝘵 𝘥𝘦𝘭𝘪𝘷𝘦𝘳 𝘢𝘤𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘢𝘣𝘭𝘦 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘪𝘨𝘩𝘵𝘴 𝘢𝘵 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘳𝘪𝘨𝘩𝘵 𝘮𝘰𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵 𝘵𝘰 𝘨𝘦𝘯𝘦𝘳𝘢𝘵𝘦 𝘷𝘢𝘭𝘶𝘦". 


💬 "𝘛𝘩𝘦𝘺 𝘴𝘩𝘰𝘶𝘭𝘥 𝘕𝘖𝘛 𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘳𝘵 𝘢 𝘥𝘢𝘵𝘢-𝘢𝘯𝘢𝘭𝘺𝘴𝘪𝘴 𝘣𝘦𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘦 𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘢𝘤𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘴 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘸𝘪𝘭𝘭 𝘣𝘦 𝘵𝘢𝘬𝘦𝘯 𝘰𝘯𝘤𝘦 𝘥𝘰𝘯𝘦. 


𝐀 𝐤𝐞𝐲-𝐟𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐨𝐫 𝐨𝐟 𝐟𝐚𝐢𝐥𝐮𝐫𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚-𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐲𝐬𝐭𝐬 📉
While these tips are great and inspirational, they highlight a key-factor of failure for data-analysts: 

"If you deliver a great insight but the product/development team is not ready to develop the recommended changes, all your data-analysis work is lost and you bring no value" 😾. 



𝐖𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐢𝐟 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚-𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐲𝐬𝐭𝐬 𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐥𝐝 𝐭𝐚𝐤𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦𝐬𝐞𝐥𝐯𝐞𝐬? 💡

At Nickel, when the team works on "out of stock" issues at points of sale, the data-analyst can, on his own:
- analyse the problem, quantify the lost value and decide to take actions,
- build a ML model to predict if a point of sale is "out of stock soon",
- automatically order some material when "out of stock soon" is predicted.

No data-engineers need to be involved nor product/development team. 

This is, we believe, how you make your data-analysts impactful: 

🏆  "You give them the power to take the actions themselves" 🏆 



𝐇𝐨𝐰 𝐭𝐨 𝐝𝐨 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐚𝐧𝐲 𝐭𝐨𝐨? 🚀

Your company probably built micro-services exposed in a catalog of apis (with one route to order material for one point of sale). What you need is to make these apis available to your data-warehouse.

That's exactly the purpose of BigFunctions: to build a catalog of advanced functions callable by data-analysts from your data-warehouse. The functions can call your company internal apis or public ones for your saas products. 



Know More about BigFunctions here: https://lnkd.in/eBzr3wfM 


👏  Congrats Hugo Mulheim for this work on out of stock issues.

Photo from August Phlieger on unsplash.

#bigquery #bigfunctions #dataanalysis #dataengineering #googlecloud

text:
When to use BigQuery Dataframes over SQL ? 


Querying your BigQuery data in SQL is very natural and efficient but you want to use BigQuery Dataframes (aka Bigframes) if:

✅  You come from the pandas world.
✅  Your sql becomes too verbose and hard to maintain and you want to group code in functions or to reuse code.
✅  You want to write scripts as it is much easier to develop python scripts than stored procedures. 

📢 𝐀𝐧𝐧𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐜𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭
Every BigFunction (to do advanced transforms) is directly available from BigQuery Dataframes (no install needed!) 


BigQuery Dataframes: https://lnkd.in/e4CMKT4w

BigFunctions: https://lnkd.in/eBzr3wfM

text:
Moving data to your Data-Warehouse has never been easier 🏌‍♂️  !

Every data project starts with moving data from different sources to your data-warehouse for analysis. To this end, Airbyte certainly provides the best open-source product with 300+ source connectors and a huge community👀. 

I created a lightweight python package (airbyte-serverless) to manage these connectors in the yaml era and I felt really honored when Modeo contacted me to showcase it to the world during a webinar. 🧡 

What surprised me is that Modeo went further than I anticipated as they used airbyte-serverless to run their own custom connectors. 💪

It was a real pleasure to meet you Ismael Goulani Lynn Farhat Matthieu Rousseau and build stuff together. I have been impressed by your teamwork actually.  🙌

I put the webinar video link in first comment. 

You like it? Add a star to GitHub!
⭐ ➜ https://lnkd.in/eYKPJtey

Paul Marcombes Ismael Goulani et Lynn Farhat nous présenterons comment utiliser Airbyte Serverless pour développer des pipelines d'ingestion ultra-performantes à bas coût.

text:
Want a demo of Serverless Data Pipelines? 

✅  Move data with Airbyte Serverless 
✅  Transform it with dbt
✅  Orchestrate with Google Workflows


Airbyte is certainly the most advanced open-source system to move your data from any source to your data-warehouse. 

But deploying Airbyte Core to manage connectors can be a hassle if you're not a Kubernetes expert. 

That's why I created Airbyte-Serverless.

I am kind of proud that Lynn Farhat and Ismael Goulani from Modeo are organizing a live demo to showcase how they use it in production for their clients.

Register here for the online event: https://lnkd.in/dnxbYGhC

Airbyte-Serverless GitHub: https://lnkd.in/eYKPJtey

Feel free to leave a ⭐ on the GitHub repo 🤗

text:
Extract info from a phone number in BigQuery 📱👀


𝐄𝐱𝐞𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐢𝐧 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐁𝐢𝐠𝐐𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐲 :

select bigfunctions.eu.phone_number_info('+33123456789', null)

and you'll get:

✅  if the phone number is valid
✅  its country
✅  its type: fixed or mobile


BigFunctions is fully open-source! 
You like it? Star it!

https://lnkd.in/emfVXKjJ

#bigquery #bigfunctions #gcp #dataengineering #dataanalytics  #googlecloud

text:
Data catalog is key for your data-mesh strategy. Why building vs buying?

I was at a (great) c2c event last night and I realized two things:

1️⃣ Without a good catalog, your data-mesh strategy will be a failure as your useful and trusted data won’t be discoverable.  
2️⃣ While there are many great vendors on this space, some companies keep building their own tool instead of buying. 

- ADEO (Leroy Merlin+) built its data-finder 
- Carrefour built its data-supermarket 
- LinkedIn built Data-Hub
- Lyft built Amundsen
And the list goes on. 


Why? 


At Nickel, we also decided to build instead of buy. As an entry point of your data, your catalog can become much more than listing assets. And vendors won’t be able to suit the specific needs of your business or your tooling. 

Actually even two of our most basic needs were not always considered:

1️⃣  Search results MUST be sorted by popularity. (And by popularity I mean usage, not an edited popularity on the catalog by some stewards via promotion or "thumb up").  When I type ˋcustomer` in my portal I have a hundred results. The most used table MUST be on top.

2️⃣ We use looker studio as BI tool, but most of the time, there’s no connector to it. Btw, I really don’t want to have all company dashboards here, only curated super dashboards with their metadata. 


I’d love to know what you think. Do you build or buy your data-catalog? Why?


C2C guillaume blaquiere Antoine Castex Ivan Beauvais Florian Caringi  Jérémy Dessalines Alexandre Côté Guillaume Gelin Mazlum Tosun Axel TIFRANI Axel Thevenot  Johan Picard Antoine Guy Clément Morizot  Michelle Gurney Dimitris Petrakis Ilias Papachristos Lucy Jones

comments.text: When choosing to "build" your data catalog, are you planning to start it from scratch or to use an existing open source framework such as Amundsen or DataHub?

author.occupation: Confirmed Software Engineer | Mines Saint-Etienne × emlyon

comments.text:
Hi Paul,
Is there a replay of your talk available ?

I'm not sure it's a question of lack of functionality: are you going to build a new  dashboarding tool if the vendors don't offer one or two specific features you need?  Did Looker offer all the features you needed at the time you chose it ?

I think the "build or buy" question is more a question of mentality and company capacity: not all companies have the skills to build a product. 

Personally, I believe there are actually 3 options for the data catalog (or other tool):
- build from scratch (risky but tailor-made, quite expensive in the short term, good ROI on the long term), 
- build from open source software such as Datahub or admundsen (customized but with maintenance constraints)
- buy (safe and not necessarily too expensive, but may only meet x% of your needs)
What do you think ?

text:
Here’s what I do when I can’t find a BigQuery function to solve a problem 👇


Yesterday, again, I needed to do a transform for which 𝗜 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱 𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗻𝗮𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗕𝗶𝗴𝗤𝘂𝗲𝗿𝘆 𝗳𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻. 🧐 (𝘥𝘦𝘤𝘰𝘥𝘦 𝘦𝘯𝘤𝘰𝘥𝘦𝘥-𝘶𝘳𝘭 𝘲𝘶𝘦𝘳𝘺 𝘱𝘢𝘳𝘢𝘮𝘴 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘢 𝘭𝘰𝘨𝘴 𝘵𝘢𝘣𝘭𝘦)



𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗜 𝘄𝗲𝗻𝘁 : 

1️⃣  𝙄 𝙥𝙧𝙤𝙢𝙥𝙩𝙚𝙙 𝙜𝙚𝙣𝙚𝙧𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙫𝙚 𝘼𝙄 𝙘𝙤𝙣𝙨𝙤𝙡𝙚𝙨 𝙩𝙤 𝙜𝙚𝙣𝙚𝙧𝙖𝙩𝙚 𝙨𝙤𝙢𝙚 𝙨𝙦𝙡 𝙘𝙤𝙙𝙚. 👨‍💻

Unfortunately, I failed, like often when I ask something not easy 😞. 


2️⃣  𝙄 𝙡𝙤𝙤𝙠𝙚𝙙 𝙤𝙣 𝙨𝙩𝙖𝙘𝙠𝙤𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙛𝙡𝙤𝙬 👀

I felt lucky as I instantly found the answer from the brilliant Mikhail Berlyant (probably the guy who successfully answers the most questions about BigQuery). 


3️⃣  𝙄 𝙚𝙣𝙙𝙚𝙙 𝙪𝙥 𝙘𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙖 𝙛𝙪𝙣𝙘𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣 by following Mikhail solution💡


👉 And  𝗜 𝗽𝘂𝗯𝗹𝗶𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗱 𝗶𝘁 𝗼𝗻 𝗕𝗶𝗴𝗙𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝘀𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗻𝗼𝘄 𝘂𝘀𝗲 𝗶𝘁. 😊



Just try it yourself ⬇️: 

select bigfunctions.eu.url_decode('https://lnkd.in/gPqbxUtF%2Fhello%3Fv%3D12345')



𝗦𝗼 𝘄𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗯𝗹𝘆 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗼𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿 𝘄𝗮𝘆 𝗮𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱! 

1️⃣ Search in BigFunctions open-source catalog. If not found: submit an issue (so that someone creates the function for you) or contribute yourself. 

Then no one will have to reinvent the wheel again !! 🚴
 

𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗶𝘁? Support ⭐️ the GitHub 👉 https://lnkd.in/emfVXKjJ

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗳𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗱𝗼𝗰: https://lnkd.in/gHZjRg5y

I would definitely recommend checking out BigFunctions, as Paul has been doing a fantastic job in creating and curating this resource. It's an excellent way to leverage existing solutions and avoid "reinventing the wheel."

Keep up the great work, Paul, and I'm looking forward to contributing and collaborating more in the future! 💼🚀

article.title: GitHub - unytics/airbyte_serverless: Airbyte made simple (no UI, no database, no cluster)

text:
Introducing Airbyte-Serverless for Airbyte & Serverless lovers ❤️


Airbyte is a must-have in your data-stack with its 𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗼𝗴 𝗼𝗳 𝗼𝗽𝗲𝗻-𝘀𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗰𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗼𝘃𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗳𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝘀𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗰𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗮-𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗵𝗼𝘂𝘀𝗲.


When it comes to 𝗱𝗲𝗽𝗹𝗼𝘆 Airbyte you have several options:
1️⃣ use Airbyte Cloud if you want a managed service
2️⃣ deploy on an instance (quite easy but not robust)
3️⃣ deploy on kubernetes (hard except if you already have a cluster running). 

This leaves you no choice if you’re a serverless aficionado who likes managed services but likes deploying yourself. 🧐

👉 Say hi to  𝗔𝗶𝗿𝗯𝘆𝘁𝗲𝗦𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗹𝗲𝘀𝘀  👀 !!


Airbyte Serverless: 
❌ has NO UI 
❌ has NO database
❌ has NO transform layer

Airbyte Serverless: 
✅ is run from a CLI
✅ is based of yaml files on git
✅ can run on serverless compute

You’ll then have a robust and scalable solution at unbeatable cost with all benefits of cloud native serverless architectures. 


𝗖𝘂𝗿𝗶𝗼𝘂𝘀? Get started here: https://lnkd.in/eYKPJtey

𝗟𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗶𝘁? Please leave a ⭐️ on the repo!

text:
You probably have too many dashboards…

… 𝘩𝘰𝘸 𝘥𝘰 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘸𝘢𝘯𝘵 𝘱𝘦𝘰𝘱𝘭𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘧𝘪𝘯𝘥 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘪𝘯𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘮𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘺 𝘯𝘦𝘦𝘥 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘰𝘷𝘦𝘳𝘤𝘳𝘰𝘸𝘥𝘦𝘥 𝘴𝘱𝘢𝘤𝘦 🧐? 


At Nickel, since we had "only one" dashboard per domain, we skyrocketed data discovery at the company. 🚀

We call them 𝐬𝐮𝐩𝐞𝐫-𝐝𝐚𝐬𝐡𝐛𝐨𝐚𝐫𝐝𝐬 (🦸‍♂️) like our very few and large data-warehouse 𝐬𝐮𝐩𝐞𝐫-𝐭𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐬 (🦸‍♀️) which ease table discovery a lot. 👀



Having a unique super-dashboard for each domain: 

✅ eases dramatically information discovery 
✅ then reduces significantly the data questions you receive
✅ helps you to consider it as a product and to focus on building a community of users to collect needs and improve it constantly (while striving to keep it light and well organized). 


Having a dedicated chat channel referenced in the dashboard is not a bad idea to collect feedback and make announcements. (👏Clément Pierson). 



Thanks Ethan Aaron  for your yesterday post which recalled me this: https://lnkd.in/eGA73qwB

#lessismore #data 

Photo from Michael Rivera on unsplash.

text:
Rule № 1️⃣ for reducing BigQuery costs: 

𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐛𝐞𝐬𝐭 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐢𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐨𝐧’𝐭 𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐞!

- I just deleted 3433 tables. 
- And I instantly felt way better. 🤗 
- Wanted to share the feeling. 😁


𝐖𝐞 𝐬𝐡𝐨𝐮𝐥𝐝 𝐍𝐎𝐓 𝐤𝐞𝐞𝐩 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐟𝐨𝐫 10 𝐲𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐲𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐬 𝐩𝐮𝐫𝐩𝐨𝐬𝐞𝐬!
𝘪𝘵'𝘴 𝘵𝘪𝘮𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘷𝘢𝘤𝘶𝘶𝘮 ✨!


Then:
1️⃣ You won't pay for storage
2️⃣ You'll pay much less for querying
3️⃣ Your queries will be more efficient  
4️⃣ You'll find your useful data more easily 



For this, the most effective are:

1️⃣ 𝐏𝐚𝐫𝐭𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐞𝐱𝐩𝐢𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 🧹
- Our biggest table at Nickel represented 30 % of our total storage. 
- It happened that sometimes we had to fully rebuild downstream models. That hurt!
- We felt better when we put a 120 days partition expiration on it. 
- I am sure you also have low hanging fruits.

2️⃣ 𝐓𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞 𝐞𝐱𝐩𝐢𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐧 𝐓𝐞𝐦𝐩 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐭𝐬 ♻️

3️⃣ 𝐃𝐫𝐨𝐩 𝐭𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐬 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐨𝐧’𝐭 𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐝 𝐚𝐧𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐞 ✨ 
👉 This is where the 3433 tables I just deleted came from 👀
(𝘐𝘧 𝘪𝘵 𝘪𝘴 𝘯𝘰𝘵 𝘤𝘭𝘦𝘢𝘳 𝘩𝘰𝘸 𝘵𝘰 𝘥𝘰 𝘐 𝘤𝘢𝘯 𝘦𝘹𝘱𝘭𝘢𝘪𝘯 𝘪𝘯 𝘤𝘰𝘮𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵𝘴)



Details here https://lnkd.in/exAyPu_C
and there https://lnkd.in/eNG4_YPy



This blog post from Tinybird inspired me to name this Rule № 1️⃣.  https://lnkd.in/eeejA-j5

authorHeadline: Head of Data @Nickel / Creator of BigFunctions

text:
Beware of dbt tests…. your money may disappear 💸

At Nickel, as dbt jobs costs kept rising we decided to take action. ☝️

This is when the great Rémi BENOIST  decided to gamify the thing and created our "𝐝𝐛𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐬𝐭 𝐤𝐢𝐥𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐜𝐡𝐚𝐦𝐩𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐡𝐢𝐩"! 🏆


𝐓𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐤𝐬 𝐭𝐨 𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐧𝐚𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐚𝐥 𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐡𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐚𝐬𝐦, periodic tips and the way he kept instilling rythm in the competition, it has been a tremendous success. 

After a quarter we had reduced our dbt run costs by 30%, had a lot of fun, and our 30 dbt contributors had reached a new level of cost awareness. 💪🚀


𝐈𝐭 𝐰𝐚𝐬 𝐨𝐧𝐥𝐲 𝐰𝐞𝐞𝐤𝐬 𝐚𝐟𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐚𝐰𝐚𝐫𝐝𝐬 𝐜𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐦𝐨𝐧𝐲 that one of us walked into the office and said out loud:

"𝘞𝘢𝘪𝘵, 𝘴𝘱𝘦𝘢𝘬𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘰𝘧 𝘥𝘣𝘵, 𝘥𝘰𝘯’𝘵 𝘥𝘣𝘵 𝘵𝘦𝘴𝘵𝘴 𝘤𝘰𝘴𝘵 𝘮𝘰𝘯𝘦𝘺?"

The championship focused on dbt models run and looked no further. 

A few minutes later one replied: 

"𝘞𝘦𝘭𝘭 𝘩𝘩𝘮𝘮𝘮, 𝘪𝘯𝘥𝘦𝘦𝘥… 𝘥𝘣𝘵 𝘵𝘦𝘴𝘵𝘴 𝘳𝘦𝘱𝘳𝘦𝘴𝘦𝘯𝘵 𝘩𝘢𝘭𝘧 𝘰𝘧 𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘵𝘰𝘵𝘢𝘭 𝘥𝘣𝘵 𝘤𝘰𝘴𝘵𝘴" 🤷‍♀️💥



𝐈𝐧 𝐚 𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐥𝐞 𝐝𝐚𝐲, we could dramatically reduce dbt costs for by applying a new strategy to our testing: do not test everything everyday! Test more often the sources, less often the results of the transformations.

We learnt a lot of lessons that day. 

If you need to remember one: 
𝐁𝐞𝐰𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐨𝐟 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐝𝐛𝐭 𝐭𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐬 𝐜𝐨𝐬𝐭𝐬!!! 🤑


#dbt #finops

Photo from Blake Lisk on unsplash.

comments.text: I find this topic very interesting! I am a bit confused as to why dbt does not offer a summary of the cost and quantity of processed data with regard to tests. It would be extremely helpful for developers and data engineers to have this information readily available to them. comments.text: Been there, done that! Another interesting approach is adding a filter to the test. Specially if your table is partitioned by ingestion time, you can test only the newest data instead of the whole table. It doesn’t apply to all tests, but it does for some and it can significantly reduce their cost.

author.occupation: Engineering Manager | Data Engineer at Factored

comments.text:
The underlying data warehouse also makes a big difference when it comes to cost (and performance) of tests:

If it is a system where data and metadata are tightly coupled, storing column statistics in the metadata catalog (e.g. #Snowflake), then many tests, e.g., the tons of `not_null` tests, can be answered from metadata already.
So sometimes it's not about testing less frequently but about using a database which does a better job at answering simple (repetitive) questions.
( BTW, this is one of the upsides of an architecture that doesn't provide the freedom of choosing a different query engine.)

Background:
On #Athena we added extra predicates to the tests in order to only scan the newly added partitions when running such tests. This works and reduces costs dramatically. But in busy tables this is still causing considerable costs and takes time.
Now on Snowflake it's a bliss to have reliable column statistics available.

PS: Athena v3 with Iceberg tables may improve the situation but in our PoC we concluded that this stack is too immature at the moment.

Thanks for sharing, Paul Marcombes!
May I ask for what kind of test where the most expensive ones? Did you see a pattern?

I have a slightly different take on the test cadence however:
I believe WHAT and WHEN to test hugely depends on your actions in case a test fails:

If a pipeline runs hourly and a test fails at 6pm. Do you do something about it right away? Or can it wait until the next morning and you just inform stakeholders? Then maybe run hourly, test once in the morning.

But for daily runs, I still see it as a necessity to inform stakeholders in the morning (does not matter if 2am, 4am or 7am) that something might be off. So I would stick to daily tests.

Can you spot all issues early by just relying on source tests? I guess here it depends a bit on the business logic added later, right?

comments.text:
Interestingly enough, a very similar problem occurred with one of our clients. After GCP began increasing their prices, they imposed limits on daily Google BigQuery spending. Much to our client's surprise, they exhausted their daily budget by 7 a.m. the very next morning. Upon investigation, they found out that a dbt test was the primary consumer of the budget.
What we've often observed with many clients is that it's not just the price of the solution they need to consider; there's also the total cost of ownership. Many times, the associated costs of using the solution are overlooked.
If you want to know precisely how much it costs to run every dbt model in your GCP environment, feel free to DM me. 😁 🤑

text:
From 1400 $ to 1 $ a month 👉 my best BigQuery optimization 🤑

𝐈𝐟 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐨 𝐫𝐞𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐁𝐢𝐠𝐐𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐜𝐨𝐬𝐭𝐬 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐦𝐚𝐲 𝐡𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐚𝐥𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐲 𝐞𝐱𝐩𝐥𝐨𝐫𝐞𝐝:
1️⃣ partitioning your tables
2️⃣ requiring a partition filter on these tables
3️⃣ clustering your tables 


𝐁𝐔𝐓 𝐡𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐚𝐥𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐲 𝐞𝐱𝐩𝐥𝐨𝐫𝐞𝐝 𝐒𝐄𝐀𝐑𝐂𝐇 𝐈𝐍𝐃𝐄𝐗 🧐 ?


𝐀𝐬 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐤𝐧𝐨𝐰, 𝐁𝐢𝐠𝐐𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐢𝐬 𝐍𝐎𝐓 𝐝𝐞𝐬𝐢𝐠𝐧𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐝 𝐨𝐧𝐞 𝐫𝐨𝐰 𝐢𝐧 𝐚 𝐟𝐚𝐭 𝐭𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞 as:
- it will scan the entire table to find that row. 
- it will be very expensive
- and very slow.

𝐁𝐔𝐓 𝐬𝐨𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞𝐬 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐮𝐬𝐞 𝐜𝐚𝐬𝐞. 
You have worked hard to consolidate a 360° view of your customers and you want to expose a dashboard to your customer care deparment so that they can look for one particular customer at a time.

𝐒𝐄𝐀𝐑𝐂𝐇 𝐈𝐍𝐃𝐄𝐗 𝐞𝐧𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐬 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐭𝐨 𝐝𝐨 𝐞𝐱𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐥𝐲 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬:
1️⃣ Create a search index on customer_id column of your table
2️⃣ Use SEARCH bigquery function to look for the data of one customer_id.


𝘕𝘰𝘸 𝘐 𝘤𝘢𝘯 𝘬𝘦𝘦𝘱 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘶𝘴𝘦 𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘭𝘦𝘴𝘴 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘤𝘰𝘴𝘵 𝘰𝘧 𝘢 𝘤𝘶𝘱 𝘰𝘧 𝘤𝘰𝘧𝘧𝘦𝘦! ☕


Details here: https://lnkd.in/ez2yBpfT
and there https://lnkd.in/eXHtWXqB

What's more, Google is expanding indexes use cases dramatically. Read this blog post! https://lnkd.in/egHEtakw

text:
Composable CDP are dead, long live Data-Warehouse Connected Products 🔌?

𝐈𝐭 𝐦𝐚𝐤𝐞𝐬 𝐧𝐨 𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐬𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐰𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐞 𝐞𝐟𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐭 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐚 360° 𝐂𝐮𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐞𝐫 𝐕𝐢𝐞𝐰 𝐬𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐥 𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞𝐬 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐬𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐥 𝐭𝐨𝐨𝐥𝐬. 🧐

That's how Composable CDP were born! 

You already have a 360° view of your customer in your Data-Warehouse. Use it instead of duplicating your data again! Composable CDP are products built on top of your data-warehouse to activate its data to downstreams tools.


But today, more and more products announce to be 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚-𝐰𝐚𝐫𝐞𝐡𝐨𝐮𝐬𝐞-𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐧𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐞𝐝 🔌. 


1️⃣ Salesforce is now connected to your data-warehouse
2️⃣ Mixpanel is now connected to your data-warehouse


𝘈𝘳𝘦 𝘊𝘰𝘮𝘱𝘰𝘴𝘢𝘣𝘭𝘦 𝘊𝘋𝘗 𝘥𝘦𝘢𝘥 🧛? 

What do you think?
I'd love to read your comments!



Sources:

- Composable CDP definition from Hightouch: https://lnkd.in/eszsvUK6
- Mixpanel connected to data-warehouse: https://lnkd.in/edq9DEk2
- Salesforce and Snowflake real time data sharing: https://lnkd.in/eFEg-bMz

comments.text: In practice,  the warehouse becomes a dumping ground for data. Instead of customer 360, one ends up having data dumps from CRMs, MAP, CDPs (event collection) etc. So now one has two copies of the same data in two places, with all the same problems of disconnected, dirty, unusable data mixed with food, actionable, valuable data. It just becomes someone else's problem now.

True! I was just talking to a customer recently who mentioned that they computed a wrong user trait on the data warehouse and sent it to 10 different tools via Reverse ETL.

comments.text:
The Mixpanel article looks like outright BS. It's saying that you can use Mixpanel to go into the data warehouse and "slice and dice it however you want", to provide deeper insights. All BI tools claim to do this as well, but in fact none do, whether you can do it depends on the data model in the DWH itself. (It also mixes up terms differentiating "analysis" from "BI" - come on.)

I think both these companies realised they need to make moves into the composable CDP direction, and they (especially Salesforce) made some steps in the right direction.

I don't think "composable CDP" duplicates data anywhere. They just grab a table that already exists and load that data somewhere else.

Dans l'épisode on parle des définitions du self-service, des challenges organisationnel, des problèmes et des solutions technologiques avec des conseils pratiques pour arriver à créer une situation fertile au self-service dans vos entreprises.

comments.text:
Tout sur le self-service analytics ou l’autonomie dans l’analyse de données. 

A écouter sur la plage ou au bord de la piscine sans modération. 

Je retiens de cette discussion avec Christophe Blefari et Pierre de Poulpiquet :


1️⃣ L’autonomie peut amener au chaos si chacun fait des choses dans son coin, avec des données différentes, des définitions différentes, des outils différents. 

2️⃣ Il semble essentiel de structurer l’approche et de centraliser les données, les transformations, les définitions. Whaly ou dbt sont top pour cela. Des personnes doivent veiller au maintien de cohérence de l’ensemble et animer la communauté des utilisateurs. 

3️⃣ Des super-tables (peu de tables mais larges et très bien documentées) et super-dashboards (peu de dashboards de référence mais bien fournis) permettent de centraliser la connaissance et sont un excellent moyen de limiter les mauvaises interprétations et diminuer la complexité afin de rendre autonome. Toute nouvelle connaissance devrait se matérialiser dans ces assets. Les animateurs aident chacun à faire cela: ce n’est pas naturel de faire ce travail en plus après une analyse. 

4️⃣ Il y a plusieurs degrés d’autonomie.

text:
Tout sur le self-service analytics ou l’autonomie dans l’analyse de données. 

A écouter sur la plage ou au bord de la piscine sans modération. 

Je retiens de cette discussion avec Christophe Blefari  et Pierre de Poulpiquet :


1️⃣ L’autonomie peut amener au chaos si chacun fait des choses dans son coin, avec des données différentes, des définitions différentes, des outils différents. 

2️⃣ Il semble essentiel de structurer l’approche et de centraliser les données, les transformations, les définitions. Whaly ou dbt sont top pour cela. Des personnes doivent veiller au maintien de cohérence de l’ensemble et animer la communauté des utilisateurs. 

3️⃣ Des super-tables (peu de tables mais larges et très bien documentées) et super-dashboards (peu de dashboards de référence mais bien fournis) permettent de centraliser la connaissance et sont un excellent moyen de limiter les mauvaises interprétations et diminuer la complexité afin de rendre autonome. Toute nouvelle connaissance devrait se matérialiser dans ces assets. Les animateurs aident chacun à faire cela: ce n’est pas naturel de faire ce travail en plus après une analyse. 

4️⃣ Il y a plusieurs degrés d’autonomie. On peut aussi rendre les data analysts autonomes pour devenir indépendants des data engineers et activer eux mêmes les données. 


Merci Christophe Blefari et Pierre de Poulpiquet , j’ai passé un très bon moment et cela m’a pas mal inspiré.

article.title: BigQuery to Datastore via Remote Functions

resharedPost.text:
BigQuery Remote Functions has revolutionised the way we design data pipelines, eliminating the need for additional overhead between teams. Thanks to the exceptional efforts of the Unytics.io team, for creating #bigfunctions (https://lnkd.in/eefpGMWc), a remarkable library collection bundled with Cloud Run deployment for BigQuery Remote Functions. With just a simple SQL query, we can seamlessly push data from any BigQuery table to downstream services like Cloud PubSub or Datastore, transforming them into events.

In my opinion, this capability may completely transform the collaboration between Analytics Engineering and Data/Software Engineering teams, enabling us to unlock the full potential of data insight through Analytics Operations. The possibilities are endless!

I'd like to express my special thanks to Alex Jones, who not only discovered the groundbreaking application of BigQuery Remote Functions for automated Model Serving in the realm of MLOps but also inspired me to implement this innovative approach across other engineering domains.

Let's embrace this new era of efficient data processing and take our data-driven operations to new heights! 💪📊 #BigQuery #DataPipelines #AnalyticsEngineering #DataInsights #collaboration #BigQueryRemoteFunctions 

- 00:42 - A common problem
- 03:52 - What if?
- 04:28 - What is BigQuery Remote Functions
- 07:06 - Introducing bigfunctions
- 09:28 - Demo 
- 15:51 - The possibilities are endless
- 19:22 - Summary

Slides: https://lnkd.in/eJGxUmF5

text:
Data-Engineering practices are changing! 

I love this very educational video from Richard Shenghua (升华) He which explains how a SQL query can export BigQuery data towards any other systems. 🤩 


It means you can now send BigQuery data directly from your dbt models or dbt post hooks ⚡:

1️⃣ to a realtime database such as datastore for fast data serving
2️⃣ to chat systems such as slack, google chat
3️⃣ to excel files sent by emails
4️⃣ to literrally any API 👀


#BigFunctions is a catalog of open-source functions to expand #BigQuery capabilities. 

If you like it, don't hesitate to star it ⭐  ! https://lnkd.in/emfVXKjJ

comments.text:
Thanks so much for sharing Paul Marcombes this really got me excited over the weekend. 

It's probably an understatement to say #bigquery Remote Functions & #bigfunctions can change how data pipelines are designed. In my opinion, this is something much bigger. The real problem it solves, is pipeline ownership issue, in the past you always need to handle the last bits to another team, let alone the issues with schedulers & latencies, most importantly, you no longer have to transfer domain knowledge to a different team. And this is all replaced with APIs calls via a SQL function. 

This in my opinion, can probably save 50%+ of the leg work on between service / team integrations. A true game changer.

text:
Expose your BigQuery data in a real-time database from `dbt` 💎 

BigQuery is perfect for massive calculations, but is not designed to obtain key-value data very quickly. 

And in the following use cases, you'd love to be able to retrieve quickly customer-profiles pre-computed in BigQuery:

1️⃣  Content personalization 📄
2️⃣  Real-time notifications 💬
3️⃣  Embedded Analytics 📈
4️⃣  Fraud-fighting 🐱‍👤


Hopefully, El-Walid Ibrahim from Esmoz created a BigQuery function to 𝐞𝐱𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭 𝐁𝐢𝐠𝐐𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐭𝐨 𝐆𝐨𝐨𝐠𝐥𝐞 𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐞 which is specifically designed to obtain key-value data. 👀

You can even use a dbt post-hook (as seen in the image) to sync your dbt model to Datastore automatically at `dbt run`  😲


Actually, you don't event need dbt. It works in SQL ⚡.
So it will also work in your dataform, sqlmesh, scheduled queries, etc.

Just try this in your BigQuery 👇:
-------------------------------------------------
select bigfunctions.eu.export_to_datastore(
    'your-project',
    'your_namespace',
    'your_kind',
    'user1234',
    json '{"score": 0.99}'
)


---
- 𝐅𝐮𝐧𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐃𝐨𝐜: https://lnkd.in/eqHcUMmn

text:
Run any python code in BigQuery  🐍


When Axel Thevenot from Devoteam came to me and told me:
👉 ❝ 𝘞𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘪𝘧 𝘸𝘦 𝘩𝘢𝘥 𝘢 𝘧𝘶𝘯𝘤𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 𝘤𝘢𝘱𝘢𝘣𝘭𝘦 𝘰𝘧 𝘦𝘹𝘦𝘤𝘶𝘵𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘢𝘯𝘺 𝘱𝘺𝘵𝘩𝘰𝘯 𝘤𝘰𝘥𝘦 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘪𝘥𝘦 𝘉𝘪𝘨𝘘𝘶𝘦𝘳𝘺? ❞

I was like:
1️⃣  Wow, this is potentially a game changer! 😲 
2️⃣  Yes, but it raises a ton of security concerns 😈


Working together, we finally managed to create that function which enables anyone to execute arbitrary python code in BigQuery while keeping things secure (thanks to sandboxing). 🚀


𝐓𝐫𝐲 𝐢𝐭! (𝘪𝘵 𝘸𝘰𝘳𝘬𝘴 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘭𝘭):
select bigfunctions.eu.run_python('return 1 + 1', null, null)

text:
Sync any dbt model into Google Sheet at `dbt run`  👌

Keep your finance team updated ✅ (or any other spreadsheet-lover ❤️) !

Thanks to dbt post-hooks and the brand-new BigQuery function from  Shivam Singh, any BigQuery dbt model can now be uploaded to a Google Sheet at the moment it is updated. 👀


Actually, you don't event need dbt. It works in SQL ⚡. 
So it will also work in your dataform, sqlmesh, scheduled queries, etc.

Just try this in your BigQuery 👇:
------------------------------------------------- 
call bigfunctions.eu.upload_table_to_gsheet(
     '(select 1 as column1)',
      1000,
      'YOUR_SPREADSHEET_URL',
      'a worksheet name',
      'write_truncate'
);


---

text:
😲 𝐀𝐬𝐤 𝐐𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐭𝐨 𝐁𝐢𝐠𝐐𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐢𝐧 𝐄𝐧𝐠𝐥𝐢𝐬𝐡  !

𝘌𝘷𝘦𝘳𝘺 𝘉𝘪𝘨𝘘𝘶𝘦𝘳𝘺 𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘳 𝘤𝘢𝘯 𝘕𝘖𝘞 𝘢𝘴𝘬 𝘲𝘶𝘦𝘴𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘴 𝘰𝘷𝘦𝘳 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘪𝘳 𝘥𝘢𝘵𝘢 𝘪𝘯 𝘌𝘯𝘨𝘭𝘪𝘴𝘩.

The BigQuery function '𝘢𝘴𝘬_𝘮𝘺_𝘥𝘢𝘵𝘢' converts your English question into SQL adapted to your data and execute it. 

To try it, simply execute the query written in first comment. 
(𝘯𝘰 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘭𝘭 𝘳𝘦𝘲𝘶𝘪𝘳𝘦𝘥!)


❓ 𝐇𝐨𝐰 𝐝𝐨𝐞𝐬 𝐢𝐭 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤?

1️⃣ The function retrieves the table schema from INFORMATION_SCHEMA
2️⃣ It asks a Google language model to generate the SQL code from your question and the table schema.
3️⃣ It executes the generated query 🚀


🐛 𝐃𝐨𝐞𝐬 𝐢𝐭 𝐚𝐥𝐰𝐚𝐲𝐬 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤? 
Probably not. 
Yet, I noted that if the names of your columns are self-explanatory, it works very often. And if it fails, the functions gives you details why and you can adjust your question. 


➕ 𝐇𝐨𝐰 𝐜𝐚𝐧 𝐈 𝐠𝐞𝐭 𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐧𝐟𝐨?
-  BigFunctions is an open-source catalog of BigQuery functions. 
-  Read '𝘢𝘴𝘬_𝘮𝘺_𝘥𝘢𝘵𝘢' doc: https://lnkd.in/ePp9pYiv


❤️ 𝐁𝐢𝐠𝐅𝐮𝐧𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐢𝐬 𝐟𝐮𝐥𝐥𝐲 𝐎𝐩𝐞𝐧-𝐒𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐜𝐞
If you like it, consider adding a ⭐  on the GitHub repo, and we'll build more!
👉 https://lnkd.in/emfVXKjJ


#bigquery #bigfunctions #gcp #dataengineering #googlecloud

text:
Generating PDF invoices from BigQuery  📄


𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐰𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐭𝐨 𝐠𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐏𝐃𝐅 𝐟𝐢𝐥𝐞𝐬 from BigQuery to:

1️⃣ Generate custom PDF reports with data
2️⃣ Generate customized PDF files by client


𝐎𝐧𝐞 𝐠𝐨𝐨𝐝 𝐞𝐱𝐚𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞 is when you need to generate monthly pdf invoices based on client consumptions. 🧐


𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐜𝐚𝐧 𝐧𝐨𝐰 𝐝𝐨 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐨𝐧𝐞 𝐁𝐢𝐠𝐐𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐲 👀 
Indeed, Guillaume Pivette from Neoxia created a function to convert html (built from user data) to pdf.  🙌


𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐥𝐥𝐨𝐰𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐲 will:
1️⃣ Get an invoice as html from internet 
2️⃣ Convert it to pdf
3️⃣ Send it to YOUR_EMAIL_ADDRESS

Just try it, you'll be amazed! 😲
(𝘪𝘵 𝘸𝘰𝘳𝘬𝘴 𝘪𝘯 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘰𝘸𝘯 𝘉𝘪𝘨𝘘𝘶𝘦𝘳𝘺 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘭𝘭)


---

select 
  bigfunctions.eu.send_mail(
    'YOUR_EMAIL_ADDRESS',
    'Email from BigQuery with PDF attached',
    '''
    # BigQuery can send personalized emails!
    Your PDF is attached!
    ''',
    'invoice.pdf',
    (select 
      bigfunctions.eu.html2pdf(
        bigfunctions.eu.get(
          'https://lnkd.in/eQd7wvDX', null
        )
    ))
)

---

(in a real world example, you would not download the html through the internet of course, but build it in BigQuery from your customer data. You can check render_string bigfunction to help you with that).


---
- 𝐅𝐮𝐧𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐃𝐨𝐜: https://lnkd.in/e8KXcpeH

text:
Generative AI is available in BigQuery and I just learned two things 🧠

Google released new language models #paLM2 this wednesday and I could not wait to add a bigquery integration. 😊

👉 𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐜𝐚𝐧 𝐧𝐨𝐰 𝐫𝐮𝐧 𝐢𝐧 𝐁𝐢𝐠𝐐𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐲:
select bigfunctions.eu.ask_bison('ANY QUESTION')  😲


So asking it the question in the image, I learned two SQL things that I didn't know:
1️⃣  We can compare timestamps with dates expressed in string.
2️⃣  In `order by` clause we can put the alias of the computed aggregate


𝐑𝐞𝐠𝐚𝐫𝐝𝐥𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐬𝐞 𝐭𝐢𝐩𝐬, what amazed me the most was that I could improve my skills so easily. 👀

I'd be very happy to read in comments how you think generative AI will help you.

document.title: BigQuery Excel Report ➜ the easy way!

text:
BigQuery Excel Report in your inbox ➜ the easy way!


Sending a BigQuery table as an Excel file to your team simply requires the execution of a SQL query 👀.

(Thanks to Guillaume Pivette from Neoxia who created the open-source bigquery function send_mail 🙌🚀)


You can now send by email any dbt model as an Excel file thanks to dbt post-hooks. Or you can use scheduled queries, or dataform, or any data app you prefer 😁. 


𝐓𝐫𝐲 𝐢𝐭 𝐧𝐨𝐰! 
Simply execute: 

----------------------------------------------
call bigfunctions.eu.send_mail_with_excel(
  'YOUR_EMAIL_ADDRESS',
  'Financial Report', 
  '''
  # Monthly Report from BigQuery

  ## KPIs

  - **MRR**: 32,343 USD
  - **Churn**: 4.2 %
  - **Subscriptions**: +3452
  ''', 
  'report.xlsx', 
  'bigfunctions.samples.natality'
)
----------------------------------------------

𝒀𝒐𝒖 𝒘𝒂𝒏𝒕 𝑴𝑶𝑹𝑬?
A𝘥𝘥 𝘢 ⭐ on 𝘎𝘪𝘵𝘏𝘶𝘣!

text:
Zero-ETL in BigQuery: there is More ➕


𝐃𝐢𝐝 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐤𝐧𝐨𝐰 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐜𝐚𝐧 𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐚𝐧𝐲 𝐀𝐏𝐈 𝐟𝐫𝐨𝐦 𝐁𝐢𝐠𝐐𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐲 👀?



By enabling data-practitioners to query data-sources without first moving the data to the data-warehouse, BigQuery has been a pioneer in Zero-ETL. 

You probably know that you can query data from bigtable, spanner, cloud sql, google sheets, files, etc using BigQuery interface. But did you know you can also query data from any API using BigQuery 👀??

--------------------------------------------------
select bigfunctions.eu.get('ANY_API_URL', null)
--------------------------------------------------




👀 Johan PROTIN from Zenika went further by creating a function to get latest exchange rates. 
𝐓𝐫𝐲 𝐢𝐭! 👇
--------------------------------------------------
select bigfunctions.eu.exchange_rate('USD', 'EUR')
--------------------------------------------------




Did I mention this is fully open-source?
𝘗𝘭𝘦𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘢𝘥𝘥 𝘢 ⭐ 𝘵𝘰 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘎𝘪𝘵𝘏𝘶𝘣 𝘪𝘧 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘸𝘢𝘯𝘵 𝘮𝘰𝘳𝘦 𝘰𝘧 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘴𝘦 𝘧𝘶𝘯𝘤𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘴.
GitHub: https://lnkd.in/emfVXKjJ

Function Doc: https://lnkd.in/gFJcDg3F


(the exchange rates are provided by https://exchangerate.host)

#bigquery #bigfunctions

text:
Sending notifications from BigQuery 💌


Sending Google Chat notifications from BigQuery has never been easier.

👉 Shivam Singh created a simple BigQuery function that you can call in SQL without install. 👀


You will then be able to:

1️⃣ Notify Produt teams about KPIs
2️⃣ Alert when there is a drop in a metric
3️⃣ Schedule notifications from dbt or scheduled queries
4️⃣ Deploy this function in one-click in your own GCP project.
 
 

Simply execute this query after replacing YOUR_CHAT_URL. 
(follow the documentation to get YOUR_CHAT_URL:  https://lnkd.in/ehyZ5zbd )

-----------------------------------------------
select bigfunctions.eu.send_google_chat_message(
    'Hello 👋',   
    'YOUR_CHAT_URL'
)
-----------------------------------------------


Did I mention this is fully open-source?

text:
Generate fake data in BigQuery


While working in a non-production environment you may want to generate fake data for testing purposes. 

Shivam Singh brought the great `faker` python library directly into BigQuery so that you can call it directly without install. 👀 


Just try the following query:

''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''
select 
  bigfunctions.eu.faker('first_name',   'it_IT')  as first_name,
  bigfunctions.eu.faker('last_name',     null)    as last_name,
  bigfunctions.eu.faker('email',         null)    as email,
  bigfunctions.eu.faker('address',       null)    as address,
  bigfunctions.eu.faker('date_of_birth', null)    as date_of_birth,
from unnest(generate_array(1, 100))
''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''


You can also deploy the function in one-click in your own project. Follow the Readme in GitHub. 💡 


Docs: https://lnkd.in/e3M6gjAG
GitHub: https://lnkd.in/emfVXKjJ

text:
De-identifying text in BigQuery


ELT has a drawback over ETL. 

As you get data without transform from your sources into you warehouse, (using fivetran, airbyte or any other modern-data-stack ingestion tool), your warehouse will contain personal data that you need to redact before exposing it to users.

This new BigQuery function from Shivam Singh that you can call without install from your project may then help you 👀. 


Documentation Link in first comment 👇 


#bigquery #bigfunctions

text:
Tonight I met Felipe Hoffa from #snowflake

Felipe Hoffa inspired me for a long time by writing content about data-warehousing and in particular:
👉 how to create functions on top of your data-warehouse to give super-powers to your data-analysts . 💥 


For instance:

1. geolocate IP address: https://lnkd.in/gTPdqfAi

2. send emails from your warehouse: https://lnkd.in/gFeTpuqk

3. various functions including text fuzzy matching: https://lnkd.in/gXar3_ZP


I'd even say it may have influenced me for my personal project:  
👉 create a catalog of open-source functions so that data-analysts stop reinventing the wheel 👉  #bigfunctions. 


Thanks Felipe Hoffa for inspiring me. 
You again inspired me tonight and I deployed this new open-source #bigquery function for time-series forecasting using prophet. 


- Felipe's article if you want to deploy the function in snowflake: https://lnkd.in/g3UTKvkh
- BigFunctions open-source repo ( 🙏  add a star if you like it): https://lnkd.in/emfVXKjJ
- prophet bigfunction documentation: https://lnkd.in/gVfndJUB


Thanks Didier Girard and Florent Legras for inviting me and make this meeting happen.
